medium: Ceramic with traces of Maya blue pigment
creditline: Gift of J. Lionberger Davis, Class of 1900

texts.textentryhtml: Hernan and Socorro B. Navarrete Collection, Veracruz, Mexico, ca. 1950. David Bramhall, by 1964; purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum through J. Lionberger Davis (1878 - 1973), Class of 1900, Princeton, NJ by May 1964.

Ancient Mesoamericans attributed illness to supernatural beings. Yet these same entities were simultaneously sources of health and curing. Differing depictions of such characters highlight either their malevolent or benevolent aspects. This elderly Maya female is Chak Chel, whose name means Great Rainbow. Among the Maya, rainbows were envisioned as the flatulence of demons and the source of seizures. This figurine likely once wielded an ax and features feline qualities, such as the large, triangular ears in her headdress, suggesting that she is a cause of illness with the ferocity of a jaguar. Another work appearing later in this exhibition highlights Chak Chel’s positive attributes as a midwife.

Armed with a shield, this Maya goddess appears as a fearsome warrior. Her snarling mouth and jaguar ears, which are attached to hair bound with ribbons, conveyed a sense of dread among her enemies. Known in later times as Chak Chel (Great Rainbow), she was a patron of midwives. Although the portrayal of Chak Chel as a warrior is unusual in Maya art, her cognate among contemporaneous Mesoamerican peoples was a military commander who led her own armies to battle. On occasion, her "weapon" is depicted as a weaving batten, which may be what this figurine once held in her empty right hand. Alternatively, she may have held an ax, as known from other examples.
